title: Between 16 October 2020 and 31 December 2021, how many successful flight tests of the Common Hypersonic Glide Body (C-HGB) will the United States conduct?
preds:
As of the date of my posting, the device has been successfully tested twice. The current schedule seems to be about three tests a year, though weather and logistics likely forbid testing in the remaining weeks of this year. Three to four tests are likely next year. The navy’s briefings on the tests…
https://www.navy.mil/Press-Office/News-Stories/Article/2827117/navy-hypersonic-rocket-motor-moves-closer-to-flight-testing/ https://www.navy.mil/Press-Office/Press-Releases/display-pressreleases/Article/2636993/navy-tests-new-hypersonic-rocket-motor/

We are certainly testing but the question of being announced is a different story. Given the situation in eastern europe and peacocking with China and Olympics I don't believe current administration would have the tenacity to be so bold.
U.S still not ready but eager
If it hasn’t happened by now, I believe the likelihood of it happening by the end of the year is slim enough to be considered zero.

Plans were made for another Air Force test to be done in Q3 of 2021, but that deadline came and went. Likelihood of 4 successful test taking place in the next 28 days is slim. It is possible, however, that successful tests could take place, or have already taken place, and the announcement about them just hasn't been made yet. Given that, I chose the percentages I did.

Looks like plans for three tests, with one past one having been successful.  So seems no chance of four tests, and it's very unlikely that none of the planned three would be successful.  Seems better than even chance that future tests will be successful, given past success, and roughly even chance, given that, that either one or two instead fail.
These flights were mentioned in the press a few weeks ago
Big thanks to @Ryan-Beck for the article he linked to. I'm adjusting my forecast accordingly.

I'm switching to favor zero. I'm basing that on time remaining and also the fact that in this interview published yesterday General Thurgood was asked if they're still on track to test the CHGB by the end of the year and he kind of dodged it by saying 3 tests in FY 2022. Doesn't inspire confidence to me, I think if they were on track for that he would have wanted to call attention to that. Leaving plenty of probability on one currently because it's possible the military doesn't like to tie that down in advance for security reasons. https://www.defensenews.com/interviews/2021/11/15/us-armys-hypersonic-supervisor-talks-tech-portfolio/

Since the test on Oct 21 failed the DoD will likely do root cause analysis to reduce the chance of another failure. This can be a long process and then a fix would have to be implemented. Plus the friction of the holidays is upon us slowing work more. Even with a different booster the irrational risk averse DoD is unlikely to conduct another test within 12 months. https://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/42837/new-u-s-long-range-hypersonic-weapon-test-fails-updated
Very recent test. Next appear to be planned for first q of next fy. Delays in manufacturing.  Only Arrw.

https://www.defensenews.com/digital-show-dailies/smd/2021/08/11/next-flight-test-of-hypersonic-glide-body-expected-by-years-end/ Test expected this quarter. 
Rollout into the military for next year & 2023 requires successful testing.
Possibility launch occurs at the start of 2022 for political effect.
Going up 5 on zero, there have been multiple delays already. Though the Chinese hypersonic weapon test may light a fire under the US testing program.

https://edition.cnn.com/2021/10/21/politics/us-hypersonic-test-fails/index.html
April was the last one. 
Doesn't seam to have enough time to study this failure and make another one.
Decided I should expand the tail a bit since very little info is publicly available.
Thank you Mr. @Ryan-Beck for the update

Significant downgrade based on the article quoted by @Ryan-Beck (thank you).
Seems 3 would be optimistic, although still fully 4 1/2 months of the year left so not totally ruling it out.

Yep this confirms it, only one test planned this year, they canceled the test that was supposed to happen recently. Still possible this test could test 2 missiles at once or something, but a result of 3 is probably ruled out entirely. Very possible they miss their window for the next test too. https://www.defensenews.com/digital-show-dailies/smd/2021/08/11/next-flight-test-of-hypersonic-glide-body-expected-by-years-end/
Another search, another complete lack of information on progress or any successful testing happening. Skewing down even more.

I've found a report from some misc. US military news site titled "Conventional Prompt Global Strike and Long-Range Ballistic Missiles: Background and Issues" (1). Running a quick key word search of  the report shows the Air Force is out and is focusing on another system and this from the summary for FY2021's legislative activity (p. 34); "the increase in funding for FY2021 “provides for platform integration and development efforts, procurement of prototype C-HGBs (common hypersonic glide bodies), [and] the increased development and procurement of missiles/missile body flight articles.” The funding would also support additional launch testing and increased efforts associated “with the design, development, and experimentation of hypersonic subsystems.” The documents indicate that the Navy still planned to conduct a second experimental flight test of the system in FY2020 and the first development flight test in FY2022.".   AND no specific mention of testing for FY2022 (p.35).  Noting fiscal years end in Sept of the designation, i.e. FY2021 runs from Oct 1 2020 - Sept 30 2021 (2). It's worth noting GOOD design and development should involve testing, but it would appear that in this case funds are specifically requested for testing, so it's hard to tell if this is a smoking gun there's only 1 test coming until FY2022, or if it's just written lazily because only the authors and a handful of key stakeholders will read it. I can't bring myself to shift heavier against the crowd at this stage, but will keep an eye out for other sources which may shed light on this question.  1. https://news.usni.org/2021/07/20/report-to-congress-on-conventional-prompt-global-strike-and-long-range-ballistic-missiles-4
2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiscal_year#United_States

This question poses some questions. As written it says: " A flight test will be considered “successful” if the U.S. military announces that the C-HGB reaches its designated impact point (Defense News)." So ... what happens if the US Military announces that it hit within 6 inches of the target, which is what happened in the first test? That's not "reaching the designated impact point", right?  Anyway, I'm going to assume that ether: a) blasting the designated impact point to smithereens; or b) the US military announcing that the test was a success will count as a success.  We have 1 successful test so far. There are, apparently, 3 tests planned for this year, and it seems far from certain that they will go forward and/or be successful.  So ... I can't see going with the heavy focus on 3. I'm going to spread my votes around.

-33 on 3. The Navy announced that they tested the first stage of the Solid Rocket Motor (SRM) which will be used with the hypersonic glide body. But the release definitely makes it sound like this is distinct from the hypersonic glide body itself, and also the release says the following: "This successful SRM test represents a critical milestone leading up to the next Navy and Army joint flight test, which will take place in the first quarter of Fiscal Year 2022, and ultimately the fielding of the CPS and LRHW weapon systems." Previous information had said there would be 3 tests this year, the first in the third quarter of FY 2021, which for the US government means April through June (the FY starts in October). So I'm wondering if this motor test was the first one they're talking about? Or maybe their schedule slipped? Or maybe the test is still happening soon and I'm just not seeing any reporting on it. Either way, I'm a lot less certain in 3 tests this year. Navy press release on the SRM test: https://www.navy.mil/Press-Office/Press-Releases/display-pressreleases/Article/2636993/navy-tests-new-hypersonic-rocket-motor/ Previous article about when the tests would happen in the fiscal year this year: https://www.defensenews.com/digital-show-dailies/ausa/2020/10/13/us-developed-hypersonic-missile-hit-within-six-inches-of-target-army-secretary-reports/

There are supposed to be two events scheduled, the first has one test and the second two. The first test will likely occur, the second may not because of problems with testing infrastructure as in the Defense One article. There is also small chance that the test is held but fails.

My forecast is based on will the USAF announce. Probably already done. The USAF is a military organization that has a culture of using technology it engineers and fields.  They don’t lie to the public but they have a history of “it’s none of your business because it’s classified”.

A good background article about the hype(rsonics) in the US, Russia, China, strengths and weaknesses of the concept over ICBM etc.
"The Pentagon’s 2021 budget request for hypersonic-related research was US$3.2 billion – up from US$2.6 billion last year – including US$206.8 million for hypersonic defence programmes." The budget increase will surely have been included to make ends meet for three test flights in 2021 (and a possible backup, if one fails), but is likely not high enough to enable plans for a fourth mission test.
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3118221/are-hypersonic-missiles-game-changer-not-so-fast-says-new-study
Going with a bigger spread just because I don’t know anything about this question but betting heavy on 3 seems irrational with a year yet to go
Going down from 100% for 3. Haven’t seen anything solidly supporting so many tests in a year. Confirmation does appear to lag event, however.

Successful test in March 2020 makes production of new C-HGB missiles faster.
Hypersonic missiles (Mach-5 or faster) are at the forefront of the new superpower arms race.
The U.S. Army, Navy & Air Force want launching capabilities between 2022-2024.
Army and Navy plans to conduct 3 flight tests in 2021... "ambitious"
Lockheed Martin; 9-figure government contract on mobile launcher
Developing the C-HGB as a base for offensive hypersonic missiles.
Typically takes multiple months before the U.S. officially acknowledges missile testing.
RESULT
Outcome 0: 1%
Outcome 1: 13%
Outcome 2: 47%
Outcome 3: 36%
Outcome 4 or more: 3%

Gjo has confirmed a successful joint exercise will resolve as a yes. I've had a little flip-flop, as I didn't see the missile designation in my first skimming of the article.  The missile tests with Australia will be of a Scramjet variant from a program called SCIFiRE, which is a different hypersonic missile design to a C-HGB. The things you learn.

Australia is going to be helping - https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/australia-to-begin-testing-hypersonic-missiles-within-months-20201130-p56j5a.html I've requested clarification if a successful test of an appropriate missile would qualify for a yes.

Increasing confidence in 3 (following the crowd a bit). Leaving 15% at 1 in case double test gets delayed (it's near the end of the question period). Leaving 10% at 2 in case one of the glide bodies is unsuccessful.
Why am I in this question?

an estimate of three min - one fore each services model, but I think ,maybe 4 to allow for a Navy Boost Rocket variant test (Possibly Sub Launched.).
https://news.usni.org/2020/11/11/report-on-u-s-hypersonic-weapon-development-3?utm_source=USNI+News&utm_campaign=599d2b4ca7-USNI_NEWS_DAILY&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_0dd4a1450b-599d2b4ca7-231045397&mc_cid=599d2b4ca7&mc_eid=2394c94b5b
Skewing a bit more toward all three on time and successful, but leaving some room in the event the double test near the end of the timeframe gets pushed back or one or two of the glide bodies fail.

A test with two C-HGBs counts as two, so that puts it at 3 attempts in 2021. I think it's most likely they're all successful. Leaving some on 2 and 1 in the event that the second test gets delayed to 2022 and on chances of test failures. Small chance of 4 in the event of a schedule change, but seems unlikely since the current schedule appears to already be described as aggressive.

I reached out to the author of the Defense News articles regarding the contradictory number of tests being mentioned and she said she believes one of the tests will involve two missiles which is why different numbers were being given. I contacted the moderators about this to see what they say, but I'm guessing that it would still count as one test. Which in that case would mean 2 tests scheduled in the timeframe, and I'm leaning toward it being most likely that both tests happen on schedule and succeed. Reply from Defense News' Jen Judson: https://twitter.com/JenJudson/status/1321876474631196689 My previous comment discussing the articles that seemed to offer contradictory testing schedules: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1171277

There seems to be some contradictory information floating around. In an interview from August General Thurgood says one test in mid 2021 and two tests in later 2021. In a defense news article from October referencing an interview with Thurgood from before the AUSA conference (which took place in October) they say a test in Q3 of FY 2021, a test in Q1 of FY 2022, and two tests in Q3 of FY 2022. Source indicating two tests next year: https://www.defensenews.com/digital-show-dailies/ausa/2020/10/13/us-developed-hypersonic-missile-hit-within-six-inches-of-target-army-secretary-reports/ Interview from August 5th, relevant question starts at 22 minutes, here he says one test mid 2021 and two tests near end of 2021: https://www.defensenews.com/native/raytheon-missiles-defense/2020/08/04/virtual-event-smd-debrief-2020/ Based on that contradictory information I feel like the one from October is more accurate, indicating 2 tests, and that the general may have mispoken in the earlier interview. Hard to say for sure. The other big factor is success, but I feel like the tests are more likely to be successful. Based on all that I give 2 successful tests the highest likelihood.

Defense News reported in August that DoD plans to accelerate the C-HGB program by having a flight test in the middle of 2021, and two more later in the year, with weapon deployment in 2023.  This accelerated effort is accompanied by a $2.9 billion budget for 2021 [2]. This schedule is aggressive as commented by DoD [1] in order to compete with the efforts in China and Russia.  To meet the schedule, each test will have meet multiple objectives which increases the complexity of the subsequent flight tests.  However, for this question a flight test will be considered “successful” if the U.S. military announces that the C-HGB reaches its designated impact point, and presumably independent of whether other DoD objectives designated for a particular test are achieved or not. Base rate:
Lets treat this as a 3 coin toss problem.  There is 1 case with all 3 tests fail, 3 cases for one successful test, 3 cases for 2 successful tests and 1 for 3 successful tests, out of 8 possible outcome combinations.  Therefore the probabilities for 0, 1, 2 and 3 successful tests are 12.5, 37.5, 37.5 and 12.5%, respectively. Inside view:
Historically complex weapon systems frequently have encountered significant delays and over the budget.  I don't see how this particular case is any different. Since the planned number of tests is 3 for 2021, it is very unlikely that >3 tests will happen, let alone >3 successful tests.  0% for the >3 basket.   There has been one successful flight test in March 2020 already [1]. It is very likely that at least one  "successful" (as defined in this question, which has a low bar) test will happen in 2021.  I put 0% in the first basket (zero successful test). I would increase the probability for 1 successful test to from a base rate of 37.5% to 50%, 2 successful tests to 40%, but reduce the 3 successful tests to 10%.  The adjustments are attempts to account for the increasing difficulties in achieving the DoD goals in subsequent tests (and not whether the glide body reaches its designated impact point alone).  The third test might not even happen in the time frame of this question due to unforeseeable technical difficulties. [1]  https://www.defensenews.com/digital-show-dailies/smd/2020/08/05/heres-how-the-dod-plans-to-meet-its-ambitious-hypersonic-missile-test-schedule/
[2]  https://breakingdefense.com/2020/04/exclusive-dod-asks-2-9b-for-hypersonics-in-2021/

There is this Defense News article sting that the military plans to do 3 testshttps://www.defensenews.com/digital-show-dailies/smd/2020/08/05/heres-how-the-dod-plans-to-meet-its-ambitious-hypersonic-missile-test-schedule/ It also says that it's ambitious so I assume there will be no more. Also if it's ambitious there is a higher risk of at least one failure. This article mentions there is still a discussion about the dangers of those weapons (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/19/magazine/hypersonic-missiles.html). So there is a slight chance that especially if there is a new government will be a change in policy and test will be delayed or stopped.

Lots of article citations of the 3 launches in 2021. If we take that at face value, we need to assume some chance that they won't be successful. In addition, we need to assume there's a good chance that 3 tests is their "minimum" number in 2021.
It seems likely there will be some movement on this program in 2021, with at least one flight. Unless something unexpected happens, I lean towards more flights later in the year.
@mchivis is correct. All articles seem to point to 1 test in later 2021...   I wonder if Trump’s moniker of “super duper missile” will stick!

Breaking Defense announced the next test is scheduled for the 3rd quarter of '21 and additional flights in the first quarter '22. This means there is one attempt scheduled during this question. 3 of the last four test were successful, and success rates get better https://breakingdefense.com/2020/04/hypersonics-5-more-army-navy-flight-tests-by-2023/ over time.

The FY21 budget has increased from $2.6B to $3.2B allowing for a schedule of three planned tests.  Although tech planning and results are hugely important in a plan like this, money is the largest driver of expensive testing.  A slight probability exists for more than 3 planned tests if the tests either fail or are hugely successful spurring more innovation.
The DOD plan is 3 in this time period. Such plans often suffer delay

They are clearly moving toward this direction - and once they start launching and testing there will be multiple launches.   There is a small chance that they come up with a new designation, or this is just a skipping stone technology, in which case they will be testing something else.
I predict there will be a minimum of three tests or more, depending on how those initial three tests go. It is a matter of keeping up with China and Russia and nobody knows who’s in the lead.
